\u03b2-hCG.value_description: A determination of the presence of Choriogonadotropin Beta protein.

miR-371a-3p.value_description: The human MIR371A wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 19q13.42 and is approximately 67 bases in length. This allele, which encodes MIR371A pre-miRNA, may be involved in the regulation of target gene expression. Alteration in the expression of this gene is associated with malignant germ cell tumors.

miR-372-3p.value_description: The human MIR372 wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 19q13.41 and is approximately 66 bases in length. This allele, which encodes MIR372 pre-miRNA, plays a role in the regulation of gene expression. Alteration in the expression of this gene is associated with development of testicular germ cell tumor and non-small cell lung cancer.

miR-373-3p.value_description: The human MIR373 wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 19q13.41 and is approximately 68 bases in length. This allele, which encodes MIR373 pre-miRNA, plays a role in the regulation of gene expression. Alteration in the expression of this gene is associated with development of testicular germ cell tumor and breast cancer.

miR-367-3p.value_description: The determination of the amount of human microRNA 367-3p present in a sample.

miR-375-3p.value_description: Human MIR375 wild-type allele is located in the vicinity of 2q35 and is approximately 70 bases in length. This allele, which encodes MIR375 pre-miRNA, is involved in the modulation of gene expression.

cfDNA.value_description: DNA that is found in blood plasma and is not associated with cells in the circulation.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

SPECIMEN.variable_description: The biological specimen of the subject used for the laboratory test.

Blood.value_description: A small volume of blood removed for testing or storage.

Peritoneal Fluid.value_description: A specimen of fluid from the peritoneum.

Bone Marrow.value_description: A biological sample containing components collected from bone marrow of an experimental subject.

Serum.value_description: A sample of serum collected for analysis.

Urine.value_description: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys. It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LAB_RESULT.variable_description: The string/text result of the laboratory test.

LAB_RESULT_NUMERIC.variable_description: The numeric result of the laboratory test.

LAB_RESULT_UNIT.variable_description: The units used for the numeric result of the laboratory test,

%.value_description: A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).

count/mm3.value_description: A count of items per cubic millimeter of sample.

g/dL.value_description: A unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one gram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one deciliter (100 milliliters). The concept also refers to the metric unit of mass density (volumic mass) defined as the density of substance which mass equal to one gram occupies the volume one deciliter.

U/L.value_description: An arbitrary unit of substance concentration equal to the concentration at which one liter of mixture contains one unit of a substance.

ng/mL.value_description: A unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one microgram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one liter. The concept also refers to the unit of mass density (volumetric mass) defined as the density of a substance which mass equal to one microgram occupies the volume of one liter.

UI/L.value_description: Unit of arbitrary substance concentration (biologic activity concentration) defined as the concentration of one international unit per one liter of the system volume.

IU/L.value_description: Unit of arbitrary substance concentration (biologic activity concentration) defined as the concentration of one international unit per one liter of the system volume.

mm/h.value_description: A unit of both speed (scalar) and velocity (vector), defined as the distance of one millimeter travelled per unit time equal to one hour.

mg/L.value_description: A metric unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one gram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one cubic meter. The concept also refers to the metric unit of mass density (volumic mass) defined as the density of a substance which mass equal to one gram occupies the volume of one cubic meter.

uIU/mL.value_description: Unit of arbitrary substance concentration (biologic activity concentration) defined as the concentration of one millionth of international unit per one milliliter of system volume.

g/L.value_description: A SI derived unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one kilogram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one cubic meter, or the concentration of one milligram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one milliliter, or one gram of a substance per one liter of the mixture. It is also a unit of mass density (volumic mass) defined as the density of substance which mass equal to one milligram occupies the volume one milliliter.

umol/L.value_description: A unit of concentration (molarity unit) equal to one one-millionth of a mole (10E-6 mole) of solute per one liter of solution.

mUI/L.value_description: Unit of arbitrary substance concentration (biologic activity concentration) defined as the concentration of one millionth of international unit per one milliliter of system volume.

mL/min.value_description: A metric unit of volumetric flow rate defined as the rate at which one milliliter of matter crosses a given surface during the period of time equal to one minute.

mcg/mL.value_description: A metric unit of mass concentration defined as the concentration of one gram of a substance per unit volume of the mixture equal to one cubic meter. The concept also refers to the metric unit of mass density (volumic mass) defined as the density of a substance which mass equal to one gram occupies the volume of one cubic meter.

mmol/L.value_description: A unit of concentration (molarity unit) equal to one thousandth of a mole (10E-3 mole) of solute per one liter of solution.

seconds.value_description: A unit of time, one of the seven base units of the International System of Units (Systeme International d'Unites, SI). The second is the duration of 919 263 177 0 periods of the specified light radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the caesium 133 atom in its ground state at 0 K. According to the convention, 60 seconds constitute one minute; 3,600 seconds constitute one hour.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LAB_METHOD.variable_description: A systematic course of action that is performed in order to complete a laboratory test.

Flow cytometry.value_description: A technique for counting, examining and sorting microscopic particles suspended in a stream of fluid.

Morphology.value_description: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same. In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.

MicroRNA Sequencing.value_description: A next-generation or massively parallel high-throughput DNA sequencing-based procedure that can identify and quantify the microRNA sequences present in a biological sample.

PCR.value_description: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase. This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

qPCR.value_description: An application of PCR that measures the products generated during each cycle of the polymerase chain reaction process in order to determine the starting amount of template in the reaction.

ddPCR.value_description: A type of digital polymerase chain reaction technique in which the sample is fractionated into thousands of tiny droplets using a water-oil emulsion droplet technology, within which individual PCR reactions occur in each droplet

Cytology.value_description: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LAB_SEQ_METHOD.variable_description: The number of molecules of a particular type on or in a cell or part of a cell. Usually applied to specific genes or to plasmids within a bacterium.

Relative.value_description: Considered in comparison with something else; dependent on or interconnected with something else; not absolute.

Absolute.value_description: Complete and without restriction or qualification; something that does not depend on anything else; not relative.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

THRESHOLD_HIGH.variable_description: The maximum level that must be exceeded for a certain reaction to occur or be manifested.

THRESHOLD_LOW.variable_description: The minimum level that must be attained for a certain reaction to occur or be manifested.

PMID_REF.variable_description: A globally unique identifier for a biomedical article, as assigned by PubMed.

BM_MORPHOLOGY.variable_description: The morphology of bone marrow blasts

M1 (less than 5 % blasts).value_description: A semi-quantitative microscopic finding indicating that 5 percent or less of the nucleated cells in a bone marrow sample are immature mononuclear cells.

M2 (5-25 % blasts).value_description: A semi-quantitative microscopic finding indicating that between 5 and 25 percent of the nucleated cells in a bone marrow sample are immature mononuclear cells.

M3 (greater than 25 % blasts).value_description: A semi-quantitative microscopic finding indicating that 25 percent or more of the nucleated cells in a bone marrow sample are immature mononuclear cells.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TRAUMATIC_TAP.variable_description: Was the lumbar puncture artifically contaminated by peripheral blood?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_IMAGING.variable_description: The age (in days) of the subject at the time of imaging.

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

IMAGING_METHOD.variable_description: The testing method/technique used to generate the observed results.

PET.value_description: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Gallium.value_description: An element with atomic symbol Ga, atomic number 31, and atomic weight 69.7. A rare silvery (usually trivalent) metallic element; brittle at low temperatures but liquid above room temperature; occurs in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores.

CT.value_description: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

PET-CT.value_description: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

PET-MRI.value_description: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

MRI.value_description: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

X-ray.value_description: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

Ultrasound.value_description: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Bone scan.value_description: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

IMAGING_RESULT.variable_description: The result of an evaluation technique using a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues that is performed to determine the presence, absence, or degree of a condition.

Positive.value_description: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Negative.value_description: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

Equivocal.value_description: A laboratory test result that indicates that a specific disease, condition, or attribute being assessed is not clearly present or absent.

DEAUVILLE_SCORE.variable_description: A 5 point scale devised to assess the response to treatment of Hodgkin and Aggressive Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Score 1.value_description: The results of the positron emission tomography are negative; there is no detectable abnormal tracer uptake.

Score 2.value_description: The results of the positron emission tomography are negative; the tracer uptake is less than or equal to the mediastinum.

Score 3.value_description: The results of the positron emission tomography are negative; the tracer uptake is greater than the mediastinum but less than or equal to the liver.

Score 4.value_description: The results of the positron emission tomography are positive; the tracer uptake is moderately more than the liver uptake, at any disease site.

Score 5.value_description: The results of the positron emission tomography are positive; the tracer uptake is markedly increased at any disease site.

QPET_SCORE.variable_description: A methodology that provides semi-automatic quantification for interim FDG-PET response in lymphoma. It extends the ordinal Deauville score to a continuous scale.

AGE_AT_CYTOLOGY.variable_description: Age in Days at Cytology Test

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

MALIGNANT_CELLS.variable_description: A term used to describe cancer. Malignant cells grow in an uncontrolled way and can invade nearby tissues and spread to other parts of the body through the blood and lymph system (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Present.value_description: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Absent.value_description: Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

CYTOLOGY_SPEC_TYPE.variable_description: The study of cells using a microscope (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Cerebrospinal Fluid.value_description: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

Peritoneal Fluid.value_description: The small amount of fluid that is generated in the abdominal cavity to lubricate the peritoneum.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AGE_AT_IHC.variable_description: Age in Days at Immunohistochemistry Test

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

IHC_TEST.variable_description: A laboratory method that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens (markers) in a sample of tissue. The antibodies are usually linked to an enzyme or a fluorescent dye. After the antibodies bind to the antigen in the tissue sample, the enzyme or dye is activated, and the antigen can then be seen under a microscope. Immunohistochemistry is used to help diagnose diseases, such as cancer. It may also be used to help tell the difference between different types of cancer (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

CD30.value_description: Tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 8 (595 aa, ~ 64 kDa) is encoded by the human TNFRSF8 gene. This protein is involved in ligand-mediated signal transduction, the positive regulation of apoptosis and the inhibition of cell proliferation.

beta-catenin.value_description: Catenin beta-1 (781 aa, ~85 kDa) is encoded by the human CTNNB1 gene. This protein is involved in Wnt signaling, adherens junction structure, and the regulation of cell growth.

GPC3.value_description: Glypican-3 (580 aa, ~66 kDa) is encoded by the human GPC3 gene. This protein is involved in the mediation of proteoglycan binding to the cell surface.

CD20.value_description: B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 (297 aa, ~33 kDa) is encoded by the human MS4A1 gene. This protein plays a role in both the activation and proliferation of B-cells.

LMP1.value_description: Latent membrane protein 1 (386 aa, ~42 kDa) is encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus LMP1 gene. This protein is involved in both the activation of nuclear factor-kappa-B family signaling pathways and the inhibition of apoptosis of infected B-lymphocytes.

EBER.value_description: Small non-coding RNA that is encoded by Epstein-Barr virus DNA and transcribed by virally-infected cells throughout the latent cycle. Expression of these oligonucleotides may be associated with the regulation of host ribosome function.

PAS.value_description: This is an all-round useful stain for many things, including glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoprotein, as well as fungi. The reaction is based on the oxidation of glycol group to aldehydes by periodate. The schiff's reagent selectively stains the aldehydes to a rose pink color. PAS is useful for outlining tissue structures--basement membranes, capsules, blood vessels, etc.

S100.value_description: A family of low molecular weight proteins that are characterized by the presence of two EF-hand calcium binding domains. These proteins form homodimers that localize either in the cytoplasm or nucleus of neural crest-derived cells and are involved in the regulation of many cellular processes such as cell cycle progression and differentiation.

NSE.value_description: Gamma-enolase (434 aa, ~47 kDa) is encoded by the human ENO2 gene. This protein is involved in glycolysis, neurotrophy and neuroprotection.

Vimentin.value_description: Vimentin (466 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human VIM gene. This protein plays a role in the localization of organelles and other cellular components.

Desmin.value_description: Desmin (470 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human DES gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of cytoskeletal dynamics in muscle cells.

CD99.value_description: CD99 antigen (185 aa, ~19 kDa) is encoded by the human CD99 gene. This protein plays a role in cell adhesion.

FLI-1.value_description: Friend leukemia integration 1 transcription factor (452 aa, ~51 kDa) is encoded by the human FLI1 gene. This protein plays a role in the modulation of transcription.

CD45.value_description: Receptor-type tyrosine-protein phosphatase C (1304 aa, ~147 kDa) is encoded by the human PTPRC gene. This protein plays a role in protein dephosphorylation.

IHC_SPEC_TYPE.variable_description: The type of a material sample taken from a biological entity for immunohistochemistry testing.

Tissue.value_description: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

IHC_RESULT.variable_description: The result from the immunohistochemical test.

IHC_RESULT_NUMERIC.variable_description: The numerical identifier of an immunohistochemistry specimen assessment result.

IHC_RESULT_UNIT.variable_description: The unit of an immunohistochemistry test result.

Number of events.value_description: A measurement of the total number of events that have occurred.

Intensity.value_description: The degree or magnitude of strength, energy, or feeling.

AGE_AT_GENETIC_ANALYSIS.variable_description: The age, in days, of the subject at the time of this analysis.

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

LESION_CLASSIFICATION.variable_description: The classification of a lesion of interest.

Primary.value_description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.value_description: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

METHOD.variable_description: The testing method/technique used to generate the observed results.

Karyotyping.value_description: The assessment of the chromosomal morphology and number in somatic cells of an individual.

Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization.value_description: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

RT-PCR.value_description: A laboratory procedure in which an RNA strand is first transcribed into a DNA complement and then subjected to PCR amplification. Transcribing an RNA strand into a DNA complement is termed reverse transcription and is done by the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

Sequencing, NOS.value_description: Next Generation Sequencing, should be used as a default value if no other details about the NGS analysis is known.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Blood.value_description: A small volume of blood removed for testing or storage.

Bone Marrow.value_description: A biological sample containing components collected from bone marrow of an experimental subject.

GENOMIC_SOURCE_CLASS.variable_description: The genomic class of the specimen being analyzed, for example, germline for inherited genome and somatic for cancer genome.

COMMON_NAME.variable_description: The non-standardized name of the mutation represented by this observation.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

STATUS.variable_description: Is this mutation/abnormality present in this subject?

Not Done.value_description: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

GENE.variable_description: A gene targeted for mutation analysis, identified in HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) notation.

CHROMOSOME.variable_description: One of the bodies in the cell nucleus that is the bearer of genes, has the form of a delicate chromatin filament during interphase, contracts to form a compact cylinder segmented into two arms by the centromere during metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, and is capable of reproducing its physical and chemical structure through successive cell divisions.

MUTATION_TYPE.variable_description: The type of mutation detected by this genetic analysis.

Deletion, chromosomal.value_description: An incomplete chromosome. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Deletion, NOS.value_description: The point at which one or more contiguous nucleotides were excised. (Source: The Sequence Ontology) Should be used when the type of deletion is not specified.

Indel.value_description: A sequence alteration which included an insertion and a deletion, affecting 2 or more bases. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Duplication, internal tandem.value_description: A duplication consisting of 2 identical adjacent regions. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Duplication, chromosomal.value_description: An extra chromosome. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Duplication, NOS.value_description: An insertion which derives from, or is identical in sequence to, nucleotides present at a known location in the genome. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Insertion, NOS.value_description: The sequence of one or more nucleotides added between two adjacent nucleotides in the sequence. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Translocation, chromosomal.value_description: A chromosomal mutation. Rearrangements that alter the pairing of telomeres are classified as translocations. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Translocation, NOS.value_description: A region of nucleotide sequence that has translocated to a new position. The observed adjacency of two previously separated regions. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Inversion, chromosomal.value_description: An interchromosomal mutation where a region of the chromosome is inverted with respect to wild type. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Inversion, NOS.value_description: A continuous nucleotide sequence is inverted in the same position. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Rearrangement, fusion.value_description: A sequence variant whereby a two genes have become joined. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Substitution.value_description: A sequence alteration where the length of the change in the variant is the same as that of the reference. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

SNV, NOS.value_description: SNVs are single nucleotide positions in genomic DNA at which different sequence alternatives exist. (Source: The Sequence Ontology)

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Monosomy.value_description: A chromosomal abnormality consisting of the absence of one chromosome from the normal diploid number.

Trisomy.value_description: A chromosomal abnormality consisting of the presence of one chromosome in addition to the normal diploid number.

Nullisomy.value_description: A chromosomal abnormality where a pair of homologous chromosomes that would normally be present is missing

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ALLELIC_STATE.variable_description: The genetic condition of a zygote, especially with respect to its being a homozygote or a heterozygote.

Homozygous.value_description: Having two identical allelic forms of a gene, one inherited from each parent, on each of the two homologous chromosomes.

Heterozygous.value_description: Having two different allelic forms of a gene, one inherited from each parent, on each of the two homologous chromosomes.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

HGVS_CODING.variable_description: If this mutation is described at the sequence/chromosome level, this is its representation in HGVS nomenclature (cHGVS).

HGVS_PROTEIN.variable_description: If this mutation is described at the translational product level, this is its representation in HGVS nomenclature (pHGVS)

ISCN.variable_description: If this mutation is described by the structure of the resulting chromosomes, this is its representation in ISCN nomenclature.

CLINGEN_ID.variable_description: This ID will allow users to find the most current clinical significance classification for this instance of variation

COPY_NUMBER_VARIATION.variable_description: If there was a change in the number of gene copies, this variable specifies the type of change.

Gain.value_description: An increase in the number of copies of the gene.

Loss.value_description: A decrease in the number of copies of the gene.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

COPY_NUMBER.variable_description: The number of gene copies resulting from this mutation.

AMPLIFICATION.variable_description: Was the copy number gain high enough to be reported as a gene amplification?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ALLELIC_FREQUENCY.variable_description: The incidence of this mutation in a population (%).

GENE2.variable_description: This should be used for mutations that span two gene locations (fusion, translocation, inversion, etc.). The gene name should be identified in HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) notation.

MOSAICISM.variable_description: Does this subject have two or more genetically different sets of cells in their body?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

MOSAICISM_PERCENT.variable_description: The numeric level of mosaicism in this subject.

ALT_STATUS.variable_description: Activitation of the Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT) pathway.

TOTAL_CHROMOSOMES.variable_description: The number of chromosomes detected on the karyotype through which this abnormality was detected.

INDEPENDENT_ABERATIONS.variable_description: The total number of aberrations / mutations / abnormalities detected on the karyotype through which this abnormality was detected.

CELLS_IN_METAPHASE.variable_description: The number of cells in the sample that were arrested in the metaphase stage of the cell cycle and used for the karyotype through which this abnormality was detected.

Normal Karyotype.value_description: The assessment of the karyotype is that it is normal.

Abnormal Karyotype.value_description: Any abnormality in the number, length, centromere position, banding pattern or differences between the sex chromosomes that is not representative of a normal set of chromosomes.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

DNA_INDEX_NUMERIC.variable_description: The ratio of the DNA content or chromosome number in a tumor sample compared to that in a normal sample.

AGE_AT_LESION_ASSESSMENT.variable_description: Age in Days at Lesion Assessment

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

Institutional.value_description: Local institutional review process at treating institution.

Central.value_description: Conducts reviews on behalf of all study sites that agree to participate in the centralized review process with imaging experts.

LESION_STATE.variable_description: A condition or state of a tumor at a particular time and a particular tumor site.

DETECTION_METHOD.variable_description: The method used to detect the extent of the disease involvement.

Biopsy.value_description: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Staging Laparotomy.value_description: Creation of a surgical opening into the abdominal cavity.

Lymphangiogram.value_description: An x-ray image of the lymphatic system using a radiopaque imaging agent.

Gallium Scan.value_description: A nuclear imaging procedure in which gallium-67 is used as the radiopharmaceutical. Gallium binds to transferrin, leukocyte lactoferrin, bacterial siderophores and inflammatory proteins and thereby can be used to localize foci of infection. It is also taken up by several tumors, thus gallium scintigraphy can be used for the staging of tumors.

CT Scan.value_description: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

PET Scan.value_description: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

PET-CT.value_description: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

PET-MRI.value_description: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

Ultrasound.value_description: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

MRI.value_description: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

X-Ray.value_description: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

Bone Scan.value_description: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

Physical Examination.value_description: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

TISSUE_TYPE.variable_description: A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Soft Tissue.value_description: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LESION_CLASSIFICATION.variable_description: The classification of a lesion of interest.

Primary.value_description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.value_description: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LESION_SITE.variable_description: Specifies the anatomic site of a localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

Abdomen.value_description: The portion of the body that lies between the thorax and the pelvis.

Abdominal Wall.value_description: Occurring in, or located in the retroperitoneum.

Acetabulum.value_description: Two cup shaped areas, one each on the lateral side of the lower pelvis that house the head of the femur to form the ball and socket joint of the hip.

Adrenal Gland.value_description: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).

Anal/Perianal.value_description: The lower opening of the digestive tract, lying in the cleft between the buttocks, through which fecal matter is extruded. | The skin around the anus

Ankle.value_description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Ankle Joint.value_description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Anus.value_description: The lower opening of the digestive tract, lying in the cleft between the buttocks, through which fecal matter is extruded.

Anterior Skull Base.value_description: The portion of the skull that is formed laterally by the orbital plates of the frontal bone, medially by the cribriform palate and crista galli of the ethmoid bone, and posteriorly by the planum sphenoidale and lesser wings of the sphenoid bone.

Appendix.value_description: Small tissue projection existing as a cecal diverticulum with a questionable history of vestigial versus specialized organ.

Axilla.value_description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk.

Axillary Nodes.value_description: One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.

Basin.value_description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Bladder.value_description: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Bladder/Prostate.value_description: The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system. It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra. The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Bone Face.value_description: Any bone that contributes to the facial structures, except those bones that are part of the braincase.

Bone Foot.value_description: One of the seven tarsal, five metatarsal, or 14 phalangeal bones in the foot.

Bone Marrow.value_description: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consiRMS of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Bone or Bone Marrow.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body. | The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consiRMS of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Bone Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Brain.value_description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Brain/Leptomeninges.value_description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium. | The two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord, the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

Breast.value_description: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Bronchus.value_description: Tubular structure in continuation with the trachea, serving as air passage. It terminates in the lung (terminal bronchiole).

Buttock.value_description: Either of the fleshy mounds in the rear pelvic area of the human body formed by the gluteal muscles.

Calcaneum.value_description: The irregular and largest tarsal bone that forms the heel.

Carpal Bone.value_description: Any of the small bones of the wrist joint, located between the radius and the ulna and the metacarpus.

Celiac Nodes.value_description: A lymph node at the base of the celiac artery.

Central Nervous System.value_description: The part of the nervous system that consiRMS of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Cervical Nodes.value_description: Any of the lymph nodes located in the neck.

Cervical Spine.value_description: The set of vertebrae immediately caudal to the skull.

Cervical Vertebra.value_description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secret the metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining the homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Cervix.value_description: The lower part of the uterus occupying the region between the isthmus of the uterus and the vagina. It is divided into supravaginal and vaginal portions.

Cheek.value_description: The fleshy part of the face bounded by the eyes, nose, ear, and jaw line.

Chest.value_description: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.

Chest Wall.value_description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Clavicle.value_description: The region of the body between the neck and the upper arm.

Coccyx.value_description: A small bone located at the bottom of the spine. The coccyx is a result of 3-5 fused rudimentary vertebrae.

Colon.value_description: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

Cutaneous.value_description: Having to do with the skin.

Cerebrospinal Fluid.value_description: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

Dorsal Spine.value_description: A spinal curve that originates at the middle of the second thoracic vertebra and terminates at the middle of the last thoracic vertebra.

Dorsal Vertebra.value_description: Any one of the seven vertebrae that start with C1, connecting the skull to the spine, and ends with C7, which joins the cervical with the thoracic spine.

Duodenum.value_description: A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.

Elbow.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Elbow Joint.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Epididymis.value_description: A crescent-like structure located in the upper and posterior surfaces of the testis. It consists of the efferent ductules and the duct of the epididymis. It facilitates the maturation of sperm that is produced in the testis.

Epitrochlear Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located above and adjacent to the elbow.

Esophagus.value_description: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Ethmoid Bone.value_description: A light and spongy bone that is cubical in shape. This bone is positioned at the anterior part of the cranium, sitting between the two orbits, at the roof of the nose. It consiRMS of four parts: a horizontal or cribriform plate; a perpendicular plate; and two lateral masses or labyrinths.

Eyelid.value_description: A thin membrane of skin with the purpose of covering and protecting an eye.

Face.value_description: The anterior portion of the head extending from the forehead to the chin and ear to ear. The facial structures contain the eyes, nose and mouth, cheeks and jaws.

Fallopian Tube.value_description: One of a pair of tubes that extend from the uterus to each of the ovaries. Following ovulation the egg travels down the fallopian tube to the uterus where fertilization may or may not occur.

Female Reproductive System Part.value_description: Any component of the female organs and tissues involved in the production and maturation of gametes and in their union and subsequent development as offspring.

Femur.value_description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Fibula.value_description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Fibular Head.value_description: The highest portion of the fibula that articulates with the patella.

Finger.value_description: Any of the digits of the hand.

Foot.value_description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Foot Joint.value_description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Forearm.value_description: The structure on the upper limb, between the elbow and the wrist.

Frontal Bone.value_description: A bone of the skull forming the forehead, root of the nose and the roof of both orbits.

Frontal Cortex.value_description: The part of the brain located anterior to the parietal lobes at the front of each cerebral hemisphere.

Gallbladder.value_description: A pear-shaped organ located under the liver that stores and concentrates bile secreted by the liver. From the gallbladder the bile is delivered through the bile ducts into the intestine thereby aiding the digestion of fat-containing foods.

Gastrointestinal Tract.value_description: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Groin.value_description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Hand.value_description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consiRMS of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

Hand Joint.value_description: The hinge synovial joints between the phalanges of the fingers.

Hand Phalanges.value_description: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Head.value_description: The anterior and superior part of a human bearing the mouth, the brain and sensory organs.

Head and Neck.value_description: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Heart.value_description: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

Hilar Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the hilar region of the spleen.

Hip.value_description: The lateral prominence of the pelvis from the waist to the thigh.

Hip/Inguinal Region.value_description: The lateral prominence of the pelvis from the waist to the thigh. | The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Humerus.value_description: The upper arm bone between the shoulder and elbow.

Hypopharynx.value_description: The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

Iliac Crest.value_description: The broad, dorsal, upper, and widest of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis.

Ilium.value_description: The broad, dorsal, upper, and widest of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis.

Inferior Limb.value_description: A bone of the leg (lower extremity).

Infraclavicular Lymph Node.value_description: A lymph node located in the area below the clavicle.

Inguinal Nodes.value_description: A superficial or deep lymph node located in the inguinal area.

Intra-abdominal.value_description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Intraperitoneal.value_description: Relating to the peritoneal cavity as the intended site of administration.

Ischium.value_description: The most posterior and ventral bone making up the pelvis.

Kidney.value_description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secrete metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Knee.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Knee Joint.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Lacrimal Bone.value_description: A small rectangular thin plate forming part of the medial orbit wall. It is located posterior to the frontal process of the maxilla and articulates with the inferior nasal concha, ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary bones.

Larynx.value_description: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.

Leg.value_description: One of the two lower extremities in humans used for locomotion and support.

Liver.value_description: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

Liver/Biliary Tract.value_description: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate. | The system that transports bile from the hepatocytes in the liver to the small intestine. It is comprised of the intrahepatic bile ducts, hepatic ducts, common bile duct, cystic duct, and the gallbladder.

Lower Extremity.value_description: The limb that is composed of the hip, thigh, leg and foot.

Lower Limb.value_description: The limb that is composed of the hip, thigh, leg and foot.

Lower Spine.value_description: Those vertebrae between the ribs and the pelvis, L1-L5 in man.

Lumbar Vertebra.value_description: Pertaining to the back or upper surface of the body; opposite of ventral.

Lung.value_description: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Lymph Nodes.value_description: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Mandible.value_description: The lower jaw bone holding the lower teeth.

Maxilla.value_description: The upper jawbone in vertebrates; it is fused to the cranium.

Mediastinum.value_description: A group of organs surrounded by loose connective tissue, separating the two pleural sacs, between the sternum anteriorly and the vertebral column posteriorly as well as from the thoracic inlet superiorly to the diaphragm inferiorly. The mediastinum contains the heart and pericardium, the bases of the great vessels, the trachea and bronchi, esophagus, thymus, lymph nodes, thoracic duct, phrenic and vagus nerves, and other structures and tissues.

Meninges.value_description: Any one of three membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.

Mesenteric Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the mesentery.

Metacarpus.value_description: Any of the five bones between the wrist and the fingers that form the skeleton of the palm.

Metatarsus.value_description: A bone belonging to the middle part of the foot located between toes and ankle. There are 5 metatarsal bones and they are numbered from the medial side.

Middle Ear.value_description: The part of the ear including the eardrum and ossicles. The middle ear leads to the inner ear.

Nasal Bone.value_description: One of two small oblong bones placed side by side at the middle and upper part of the face.

Nasal Cavity.value_description: The proximal portion of the respiratory passages on either side of the nasal septum lying between the floor of the cranium and the roof of the mouth and extending from the face to the pharynx. The nasal cavity is lined with ciliated mucosa, extending from the nares to the pharynx.

Nasal Cavity and Paranasal Sinuses.value_description: The proximal portion of the respiratory passages on either side of the nasal septum lying between the floor of the cranium and the roof of the mouth and extending from the face to the pharynx. The nasal cavity is lined with ciliated mucosa, extending from the nares to the pharynx. | Any one of the air-filled spaces within the ethmoid, frontal, maxillary, or sphenoid bones, which communicate with the nasal cavity.

Nasal Septum.value_description: The thin wall between the two nasal cavities.

Nasopharynx.value_description: The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.

Neck.value_description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Occipital Bone.value_description: The trapezoidal-shaped bone that forms the back and part of the base of the skull.

Occiptial Cortex.value_description: One of the four regions of cortex in each cerebral hemisphere. It is located posterior to the temporal lobe and inferior to the parietal lobe.

Omentum/Peritoneum.value_description: A fold of peritoneum originating at the stomach and supporting the viscera.

Oral Cavity.value_description: The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.

Orbit.value_description: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

Oropharynx.value_description: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.

Ovary.value_description: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.

Pancreas.value_description: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

Paraaortic Lymph Node.value_description: A lymph node located adjacent to the lumbar region of the spine.

Paranasal Sinuses.value_description: Any one of the air-filled spaces within the ethmoid, frontal, maxillary, or sphenoid bones, which communicate with the nasal cavity.

Paraspinal.value_description: Pertaining to muscles and/or tissue adjacent to the spinal column.

Paratesticular.value_description: A small anatomical compartment that contains the testicular collecting system, and mesothelial and mesenchymal components that represent extensions of the abdominal cavity and retroperitoneum.

Parietal Bone.value_description: One of two cranial bones that by their union form the sides and roof of the skull.

Parietal Cortex.value_description: One of the lobes of the cerebral hemisphere located superiorly to the occipital lobe and posteriorly to the frontal lobe. Cognition and visuospatial processing are its main functions.

Parotid.value_description: The largest of the three paired salivary glands, located in front of the ear.

Patella.value_description: A small flat triangular bone in front of the knee that articulates with the femur and protects the knee joint.

Pectoral Nodes.value_description: An axillary lymph node located along the lower edge of the pectoralis minor.

Pelvis.value_description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Penis.value_description: The male organ of urination and copulation.

Perineum.value_description: The area located between the anus and vulva in females, and anus and scrotum in males.

Peritoneum.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consiRMS of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.

Pineal.value_description: A small endocrine gland in the brain, situated beneath the back part of the corpus callosum, that secretes melatonin.

Pleura.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the thoracic cavity and the surface of the lungs.

Pleural Effusion.value_description: Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

Popliteal Nodes.value_description: Lymph node located within the fat layer of the knee joint.

Preauricular Lymph Node.value_description: A lymph node located anterior to the auricle of the ear. (NCI)

Prostate.value_description: The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system. It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra. The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.

Radius Bone.value_description: The long bone of the forearm that extends from the lateral aspect of the elbow to the thumb-side of the wrist.

Rectum.value_description: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Retroperitoneum.value_description: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run.

Rib.value_description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk. The long curved bones which form the rib cage. Generally, ribs 1 to 7 are connected to the sternum by their costal cartilages and are called true ribs, whereas ribs 8 to 12 are termed false ribs.

Sacral Region.value_description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Sacrum.value_description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Sacrococcygeal.value_description: The amphiarthrodial joint between the sacrum and coccyx.

Salivary Gland.value_description: An exocrine gland that secretes saliva. Salivary glands are mostly located in and around the oral cavity.

Scalp.value_description: The skin which covers the top of the head and which is usually covered by hair.

Scapula.value_description: One of the five bones situated between the thoracic vertebrae and the sacrum in the lower part of the spine.

Shoulder.value_description: The flat triangle-shaped bone that connects the humerus with the clavicle in the back of the shoulder.

Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Shoulder Joint.value_description: A ball-and-socket joint at the upper end of the humerus, located at the junction of humerus and scapula.

Skin.value_description: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consiRMS of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

Skull.value_description: The bones that form the head, made up of the bones of the braincase and face.

Small Intestine.value_description: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Soft Tissue.value_description: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

Spheniod Bone.value_description: The butterfly-shaped bone located at the base of the skull that helps to form the orbit of the eye.

Spinal Cord.value_description: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.

Spine.value_description: A series of bones, muscles, tendons, and other tissues reaching from the base of the skull to the tailbone. The vertebral column forms the axis of the skeleton and encloses as well as protects the spinal cord and the fluid surrounding the spinal cord.

Spleen.value_description: An organ that is part of the hematopoietic and immune systems. It is composed of the white pulp and the red pulp and is surrounded by a capsule. It is located in the left hypochondriac region. Its functions include lymphocyte production, blood cell storage, and blood cell destruction.

Splenic Hilar Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the hilar region of the spleen.

Sternum.value_description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Stomach.value_description: An organ located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine. The stomach is the primary organ of food digestion.

Superior Maxilla.value_description: The facial bone that forms the mediala floor of the orbit.

Supraclavicular Lymph Node.value_description: A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

Suprasellar/Neurohypophyseal.value_description: The area above or over the sella turcica.

Talus.value_description: The bone of the foot that connects with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

Tarsal Bone.value_description: Any one of the seven bones forming the instep of the foot.

Temporal Bone.value_description: A large irregular bone situated at the base and side of the skull, connected with the mandible via the temporomandibular joint. The temporal bone consiRMS of the squamous, tympanic and petrous parts. The petrous portion of the temporal bone contains the vestibulocochlear organ of the inner ear.

Temporal Cortex.value_description: One of the cerebral lobes. It is located inferior to the frontal and parietal lobes and anterior to the occipital lobe.

Testis.value_description: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

Thalamus.value_description: An ovoid mass composed predominantly of gray substance and associated laminae of white substance. The thalamus is divided into anterior, medial, and lateral parts. The function of the thalamus is to relay sensory impulses and cerebellar and basal ganglia projections to the cerebral cortex. The thalamus is positioned within the posterior part of the diencephalon forming most of each lateral wall of the third ventricle.

Thigh.value_description: A part of the lower limb, located between hip and knee.

Thoracic Vertebra.value_description: One of 12 vertebrae in the human vertebral column. The thoracic vertebrae are situated between the seventh cervical vertebra down to the first lumbar vertebra.

Thorax.value_description: The division of the body lying between the neck and the abdomen.

Thyroid.value_description: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

Tibia.value_description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Toe.value_description: One of the terminal digits of the foot.

Tonsil.value_description: The two organs situated in the throat on either side of the narrow passage from the mouth to the pharynx. They are composed of lymphoid tissues.

Trunk.value_description: The body excluding the head and neck and limbs.

Ulna.value_description: One of the bones that comprise the forearm. The largest aspect articulates with the humerus at the elbow joint and the smallest portion of the ulna articulates with the carpal bones in the wrist.

Upper Airway.value_description: The sinuses and those parts of the respiratory system above the trachea. It includes the nares, nasopharynx, oropharynx, larynx, vocal cords, glottis and upper trachea.

Upper Arm.value_description: The portion of the upper extremity between the shoulder and the elbow. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole superior limb.

Upper Extremity.value_description: The region of the body that includes the arm, the forearm, and hand.

Upper Limb.value_description: The region of the body that includes the arm, the forearm, and hand.

Ureter.value_description: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

Uterus.value_description: A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.

Vagina.value_description: The female genital canal, extending from the uterus to the vulva.

Vulva.value_description: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.

Waldeyer's Ring.value_description: The ring of lymphoid tissue located in the pharynx, consisting of the pharyngeal, tubal, palatine, and lingual tonsils.

Wrist.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Wrist Joint.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Zygomatic Bone.value_description: The union at the zygomaticotemporal suture of the temporal process of the zygomatic one and zygomatic process of the temporal bone.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.
Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Cranial-Caudal.value_description: A measure of the craniocaudal dimension of the tumor.

Transverse.value_description: A measure of the transaxial dimension of the tumor.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

<200 mL.value_description: A finding of a tumor volume that is less than 200 milliters.

>=200 mL.value_description: A finding of a tumor volume that is equal to or greater than 200 milliters.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

DEPTH.variable_description: The extent downward or inward; the perpendicular measurement from the surface downward to determine deepness.

Superficial.value_description: Of little substance or significance; involving only a surface.

Surface.value_description: The extended two-dimensional outer boundary of a three-dimensional object.

Cortical.value_description: The dense or compact outer layer of tissue that covers the bone.

Intra-Medullary.value_description: Occurring in, or located within the spinal cord or the marrow space of a bone.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Left.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the left side of the specimen.

Right.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the right side of the specimen.

Midline.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the midline of the specimen.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Abdominal Wall.value_description: The tissues that surround the organs that are present within the abdominal cavity. The abdominal wall tissue is composed of layers of fat, parietal peritoneum, fascia, and muscles.

Acetabulum.value_description: Two cup shaped areas, one each on the lateral side of the lower pelvis that house the head of the femur to form the ball and socket joint of the hip.

Adjacent Organ.value_description: An organ that is next to an organ of interest.

Ankle.value_description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Axilla.value_description: The underside concavity where the arm and the shoulder are joined.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Buttock.value_description: Either of the fleshy mounds in the rear pelvic area of the human body formed by the gluteal muscles.

Calcaneum.value_description: The irregular and largest tarsal bone that forms the heel.

Carpal Bone.value_description: Any of the small bones of the wrist joint, located between the radius and the ulna and the metacarpus.

Cervical Vertebra.value_description: Any one of the seven vertebrae that start with C1, connecting the skull to the spine, and ends with C7, which joins the cervical with the thoracic spine.

Chest Wall.value_description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Clavicle.value_description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Cranium.value_description: The bones that form the head, made up of the bones of the braincase and face.

Dermis.value_description: The inner layer of the two main layers of the skin. The dermis has connective tissue, blood vessels, oil and sweat glands, nerves, hair follicles, and other structures. It is made up of a thin upper layer called the papillary dermis, and a thick lower layer called the reticular dermis.

Elbow.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.
