Carmustine alkylates and cross-links DNA during all phases of the cell cycle, resulting in disruption of DNA function, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis. This agent also carbamoylates proteins, including DNA repair enzymes, resulting in an enhanced cytotoxic effect. Carmustine is highly lipophilic and crosses the blood-brain barrier readily. (NCI04)

Cisplatin.value_description: An alkylating-like inorganic platinum agent (cis-diamminedichloroplatinum) with antineoplastic activity. Cisplatin forms highly reactive, charged, platinum complexes which bind to nucleophilic groups such as GC-rich sites in DNA inducing intrastrand and interstrand DNA cross-links, as well as DNA-protein cross-links. These cross-links result in apoptosis and cell growth inhibition.

Cyclophosphamide.value_description: A synthetic alkylating agent chemically related to the nitrogen mustards with antineoplastic and immunosuppressive activities. In the liver, cyclophosphamide is converted to the active metabolites aldophosphamide and phosphoramide mustard, which bind to DNA, thereby inhibiting DNA replication and initiating cell death.

Cytarabine.value_description: An antimetabolite analogue of cytidine with a modified sugar moiety (arabinose instead of ribose). Cytarabine is converted to the triphosphate form within the cell and then competes with cytidine for incorporation into DNA. Because the arabinose sugar sterically hinders the rotation of the molecule within DNA, DNA replication ceases, specifically during the S phase of the cell cycle. This agent also inhibits DNA polymerase, resulting in a decrease in DNA replication and repair. (NCI04)

Dacarbazine.value_description: A triazene derivative with antineoplastic activity. Dacarbazine alkylates and cross-links DNA during all phases of the cell cycle, resulting in disruption of DNA function, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis. (NCI04)

Dexamethasone.value_description: A synthetic adrenal corticosteroid with potent anti-inflammatory properties. In addition to binding to specific nuclear steroid receptors, dexamethasone also interferes with NF-kB activation and apoptotic pathways. This agent lacks the salt-retaining properties of other related adrenal hormones. (NCI04)

Doxorubicin.value_description: An anthracycline antibiotic with antineoplastic activity. Doxorubicin, isolated from the bacterium Streptomyces peucetius var. caesius, is the hydroxylated congener of daunorubicin. Doxorubicin intercalates between base pairs in the DNA helix, thereby preventing DNA replication and ultimately inhibiting protein synthesis. Additionally, doxorubicin inhibits topoisomerase II which results in an increased and stabilized cleavable enzyme-DNA linked complex during DNA replication and subsequently prevents the ligation of the nucleotide strand after double-strand breakage. Doxorubicin also forms oxygen free radicals resulting in cytotoxicity secondary to lipid peroxidation of cell membrane lipids; the formation of oxygen free radicals also contributes to the toxicity of the anthracycline antibiotics, namely the cardiac and cutaneous vascular effects.

Etoposide Phosphate.value_description: A phosphate salt of a semisynthetic derivative of podophyllotoxin. Etoposide binds to the enzyme topoisomerase II, inducing double-strand DNA breaks, inhibiting DNA repair, and resulting in decreased DNA synthesis and tumor cell proliferation. Cells in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle are most sensitive to this agent. (NCI04)

Etoposide.value_description: A semisynthetic derivative of podophyllotoxin, a substance extracted from the mandrake root Podophyllum peltatum. Possessing potent antineoplastic properties, etoposide binds to and inhibits topoisomerase II and its function in ligating cleaved DNA molecules, resulting in the accumulation of single- or double-strand DNA breaks, the inhibition of DNA replication and transcription, and apoptotic cell death. Etoposide acts primarily in the G2 and S phases of the cell cycle. (NCI04)

Fludarabine.value_description: A fluorinated nucleotide antimetabolite analog of the antiviral agent vidarabine (ara-A) with antineoplastic activity. Administered parenterally as a phosphate salt, fludarabine phosphate is rapidly dephosphorylated to 2-fluoro-ara-A and then phosphorylated intracellularly by deoxycytidine kinase to the active triphosphate, 2-fluoro-ara-ATP. This metabolite may inhibit DNA polymerase alpha, ribonucleotide reductase and DNA primase, thereby interrupting DNA synthesis and inhibiting tumor cell growth. (NCI04)

Gemcitabine.value_description: A broad-spectrum antimetabolite and deoxycytidine analogue with antineoplastic activity. Upon administration, gemcitabine is converted into the active metabolites difluorodeoxycytidine diphosphate (dFdCDP) and difluorodeoxycytidine triphosphate (dFdCTP) by deoxycytidine kinase. dFdCTP competes with deoxycytidine triphosphate (dCTP) and is incorporated into DNA. This locks DNA polymerase thereby resulting in "masked termination" during DNA replication. On the other hand, dFdCDP inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, thereby decreasing the deoxynucleotide pool available for DNA synthesis. The reduction in the intracellular concentration of dCTP potentiates the incorporation of dFdCTP into DNA.

Ifosfamide.value_description: A synthetic analogue of the nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide with antineoplastic activity. Ifosfamide alkylates and forms DNA crosslinks, thereby preventing DNA strand separation and DNA replication. This agent is a prodrug that must be activated through hydroxylation by hepatic microsomal enzymes. (NCI04)

Melphalan.value_description: A phenylalanine derivative of nitrogen mustard with antineoplastic activity. Melphalan alkylates DNA at the N7 position of guanine and induces DNA inter-strand cross-linkages, resulting in the inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis and cytotoxicity against both dividing and non-dividing tumor cells.

Methotrexate.value_description: An antimetabolite and antifolate agent with antineoplastic and immunosuppressant activities. Methotrexate binds to and inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, resulting in inhibition of purine nucleotide and thymidylate synthesis and, subsequently, inhibition of DNA and RNA syntheses. Methotrexate also exhibits potent immunosuppressant activity although the mechanism(s) of actions is unclear.

Nitrogen Mustard.value_description: A synthetic agent related to sulphur mustard with antineoplastic and immunosuppressive properties. Nitrogen mustard (a member of a family of chemotherapy agents including cyclophosphamide and chlorambucil) is an irritant and carcinogenic agent metabolized to a highly reactive ethylene immonium derivative; the ethylene immonium derivative alkylates DNA and inhibits DNA replication. This agent also exhibits lympholytic properties. (NCI04)

Nivolumab.value_description: A fully human immunoglobulin (Ig) G4 monoclonal antibody directed against the negative immunoregulatory human cell surface receptor programmed death-1 (PD-1, PCD-1) with immune checkpoint inhibitory and antineoplastic activities. Upon administration, nivolumab binds to and blocks the activation of PD-1, an immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) transmembrane protein, by its ligands programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1), which is overexpressed on certain cancer cells, and programmed cell death ligand 2 (PD-L2), which is primarily expressed on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). This results in the activation of T-cells and cell-mediated immune responses against tumor cells. Activated PD-1 negatively regulates T-cell activation and plays a key role in tumor evasion from host immunity.

Pembrolizumab.value_description: A humanized monoclonal immunoglobulin (Ig) G4 antibody directed against human cell surface receptor PD-1 (programmed death-1 or programmed cell death-1) with potential immune checkpoint inhibitory and antineoplastic activities. Upon administration, pembrolizumab binds to PD-1, an inhibitory signaling receptor expressed on the surface of activated T cells, and blocks the binding to and activation of PD-1 by its ligands, which results in the activation of T-cell-mediated immune responses against tumor cells. The ligands for PD-1 include programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1), overexpressed on certain cancer cells, and programmed cell death ligand 2 (PD-L2), which is primarily expressed on APCs. Activated PD-1 negatively regulates T-cell activation and plays a key role in in tumor evasion from host immunity.

Prednisone.value_description: A synthetic glucocorticoid with anti-inflammatory and immunomodulating properties. After cell surface receptor attachment and cell entry, prednisone enters the nucleus where it binds to and activates specific nuclear receptors, resulting in an altered gene expression and inhibition of proinflammatory cytokine production. This agent also decreases the number of circulating lymphocytes, induces cell differentiation, and stimulates apoptosis in sensitive tumor cell populations.

Procarbazine.value_description: A methylhydrazine derivative with antineoplastic and mutagenic activities. Although the exact mode of cytotoxicity has not been elucidated, procarbazine, after metabolic activation, appears to inhibit the trans-methylation of methionine into transfer RNA (t-RNA), thereby preventing protein synthesis and consequently DNA and RNA synthesis. This agent may also undergo auto-oxidation, resulting in the formation of cytotoxic free radicals which damage DNA through an alkylation reaction.

Thiotepa.value_description: A polyfunctional, organophosphorus alkylating agent and a stable derivative of N,N',N''-triethylenephosphoramide (TEPA), with antineoplastic activity. Upon administration, thiotepa is converted into highly reactive ethylenimine groups, which covalently bind to nucleophilic groups in DNA and demonstrate a preference for the N7 position of guanine bases. This induces crosslinking of alkylated guanine bases in double-stranded DNA, interferes with both DNA replication and cell division, and results in both the induction of apoptosis and the inhibition of cell growth.

Vinorelbine.value_description: A semisynthetic vinca alkaloid. Vinorelbine binds to tubulin and prevents formation of the mitotic spindle, resulting in the arrest of tumor cell growth in metaphase. This agent may also interfere with amino acid, cyclic AMP. and glutathione metabolism; calmodulin-dependent Ca++ -transport ATPase activity; cellular respiration; and nucleic acid and lipid biosynthesis.

Vinblastine.value_description: A natural alkaloid isolated from the plant Vinca rosea Linn. Vinblastine binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule formation, resulting in disruption of mitotic spindle assembly and arrest of tumor cells in the M phase of the cell cycle. This agent may also interfere with amino acid, cyclic AMP, and glutathione metabolism; calmodulin-dependent Ca++ -transport ATPase activity; cellular respiration; and nucleic acid and lipid biosynthesis. (NCI04)

Vincristine.value_description: A natural alkaloid isolated from the plant Vinca rosea Linn. Vincristine binds irreversibly to microtubules and spindle proteins in S phase of the cell cycle and interferes with the formation of the mitotic spindle, thereby arresting tumor cells in metaphase. This agent also depolymerizes microtubules and may also interfere with amino acid, cyclic AMP, and glutathione metabolism; calmodulin-dependent Ca++ -transport ATPase activity; cellular respiration; and nucleic acid and lipid biosynthesis. (NCI04)

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

AGE_AT_RT_START.variable_description: Age in Days at Start of Radiation Therapy

AGE_AT_RT_END.variable_description: Age in Days at End of Radiation Therapy

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

PROTOCOL_RADIATION_THERAPY.variable_description: Was this radiation therapy administration part of the treatment protocol?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

NON_PROTOCOL_TIMING.variable_description: If a non-protocol radiation therapy, when was this radiation therapy administered?

Prior to Study.value_description: The time period before the study.

After Study Completion.value_description: The time period after the completion of the study.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Primary.value_description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.value_description: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Soft Tissue.value_description: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Abdomen.value_description: The portion of the body that lies between the thorax and the pelvis.

Abdominal Wall.value_description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Adrenal.value_description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Ankle.value_description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Ankle Joint.value_description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Anus.value_description: The lower opening of the digestive tract, lying in the cleft between the buttocks, through which fecal matter is extruded.

Appendix.value_description: Small tissue projection existing as a cecal diverticulum with a questionable history of vestigial versus specialized organ.

Axilla.value_description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Bladder.value_description: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Bone Face.value_description: Any bone that contributes to the facial structures, except those bones that are part of the braincase.

Bone Foot.value_description: One of the seven tarsal, five metatarsal, or 14 phalangeal bones in the foot.

Bone Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Brain.value_description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Breast.value_description: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Bronchus.value_description: Tubular structure in continuation with the trachea, serving as air passage. It terminates in the lung (terminal bronchiole).

Buttock.value_description: Either of the fleshy mounds in the rear pelvic area of the human body formed by the gluteal muscles.

Carpal.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Cervical Spine.value_description: The set of vertebrae immediately caudal to the skull.

Chest.value_description: The anterior side of the thorax from the neck to the abdomen. The shape of the chest is often regarded as potential insight into a disease process, as in the case of barrel chest and respiratory dysfunction.

Chest Wall.value_description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Clavicle.value_description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Coccyx.value_description: A small bone located at the bottom of the spine. The coccyx is a result of 3-5 fused rudimentary vertebrae.

Colon.value_description: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

Cutaneous.value_description: Having to do with the skin.

Dorsal Spine.value_description: A spinal curve that originates at the middle of the second thoracic vertebra and terminates at the middle of the last thoracic vertebra.

Duodenum.value_description: A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.

Elbow.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Elbow Joint.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Epididymis.value_description: A crescent-like structure located in the upper and posterior surfaces of the testis. It consists of the efferent ductules and the duct of the epididymis. It facilitates the maturation of sperm that is produced in the testis.

Esophagus.value_description: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Ethmoid.value_description: A light and spongy bone that is cubical in shape. This bone is positioned at the anterior part of the cranium, sitting between the two orbits, at the roof of the nose. It consists of four parts: a horizontal or cribriform plate; a perpendicular plate; and two lateral masses or labyrinths.

Fallopian Tube.value_description: One of a pair of tubes that extend from the uterus to each of the ovaries. Following ovulation the egg travels down the fallopian tube to the uterus where fertilization may or may not occur.

Femur.value_description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Fibula.value_description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Finger.value_description: Any of the digits of the hand.

Foot.value_description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Forearm.value_description: The structure on the upper limb, between the elbow and the wrist.

Gallbladder.value_description: A pear-shaped organ located under the liver that stores and concentrates bile secreted by the liver. From the gallbladder the bile is delivered through the bile ducts into the intestine thereby aiding the digestion of fat-containing foods.

Gastrointestinal Tract.value_description: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Groin.value_description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Hand.value_description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consists of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

Hand Phalanges.value_description: The hinge synovial joints between the phalanges of the fingers.

Head and Neck.value_description: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Heart.value_description: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

Humerus.value_description: The upper arm bone between the shoulder and elbow.

Inferior Limb.value_description: A bone of the leg (lower extremity).

Kidney.value_description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secrete metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Knee.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Knee Joint.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Large Vessels.value_description: Any of the major arteries or veins attached to the cardiac atria or ventricles. This includes the aorta, superior and inferior vena cava and the pulmonary arteries and veins.

Larynx.value_description: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.

Leg.value_description: The portion of the lower extremity between the knee and the ankle. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole inferior limb.

Lower Limb.value_description: The limb that is composed of the hip, thigh, leg and foot.

Lumbar Spine.value_description: Those vertebrae between the ribs and the pelvis, L1-L5 in man.

Lung.value_description: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Lymph Nodes.value_description: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Mandible.value_description: The lower jaw bone holding the lower teeth.

Maxilla.value_description: The upper jawbone in vertebrates; it is fused to the cranium.

Meninges.value_description: Any one of three membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.

Metacarpals.value_description: Any of the five bones between the wrist and the fingers that form the skeleton of the palm.

Metatarsals.value_description: A bone belonging to the middle part of the foot located between toes and ankle. There are 5 metatarsal bones and they are numbered from the medial side.

Nasal Septum.value_description: The thin wall between the two nasal cavities.

Neck.value_description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Oral Cavity.value_description: The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.

Orbit.value_description: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

Ovary.value_description: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.

Pancreas.value_description: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

Paratesticular.value_description: A small anatomical compartment that contains the testicular collecting system, and mesothelial and mesenchymal components that represent extensions of the abdominal cavity and retroperitoneum.

Patella.value_description: A small flat triangular bone in front of the knee that articulates with the femur and protects the knee joint.

Pelvis.value_description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Penis.value_description: The male organ of urination and copulation.

Peritoneum.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consists of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.

Pleura.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the thoracic cavity and the surface of the lungs.

Prostate.value_description: The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system. It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra. The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.

Radius.value_description: The long bone of the forearm that extends from the lateral aspect of the elbow to the thumb-side of the wrist.

Rectum.value_description: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Rib.value_description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk. The long curved bones which form the rib cage. Generally, ribs 1 to 7 are connected to the sternum by their costal cartilages and are called true ribs, whereas ribs 8 to 12 are termed false ribs.

Sacrum.value_description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Salivary Gland.value_description: An exocrine gland that secretes saliva. Salivary glands are mostly located in and around the oral cavity.

Scapula.value_description: The flat triangle-shaped bone that connects the humerus with the clavicle in the back of the shoulder.

Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Shoulder Joint.value_description: A ball-and-socket joint at the upper end of the humerus, located at the junction of humerus and scapula.

Skull.value_description: The bones that form the head, made up of the bones of the braincase and face.

Skull and Face Bone.value_description: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Small Intestine.value_description: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Spleen.value_description: An organ that is part of the hematopoietic and immune systems. It is composed of the white pulp and the red pulp and is surrounded by a capsule. It is located in the left hypochondriac region. Its functions include lymphocyte production, blood cell storage, and blood cell destruction.

Sternum.value_description: The long, flat bone connecting with the cartilages of the first seven ribs and the clavicle.

Stomach.value_description: An organ located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine. The stomach is the primary organ of food digestion.

Tarsals.value_description: Any one of the seven bones forming the instep of the foot.

Testes.value_description: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

Thalamus.value_description: A part of the lower limb, located between hip and knee.

Thorax Internal.value_description: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

Thyroid.value_description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Tibia.value_description: One of the terminal digits of the foot.

Tonsil.value_description: The two organs situated in the throat on either side of the narrow passage from the mouth to the pharynx. They are composed of lymphoid tissues.

Ulna.value_description: One of the bones that comprise the forearm. The largest aspect articulates with the humerus at the elbow joint and the smallest portion of the ulna articulates with the carpal bones in the wrist.

Upper Arm.value_description: The portion of the upper extremity between the shoulder and the elbow. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole superior limb.

Upper Extremity.value_description: The region of the body that includes the arm, the forearm, and hand.

Upper Limb.value_description: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

Ureter.value_description: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

Uterus.value_description: A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.

Vagina.value_description: The female genital canal, extending from the uterus to the vulva.

Vulva.value_description: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.

Wrist.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Wrist Joint.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Left.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the left side of the specimen.

Right.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the right side of the specimen.

Bilateral.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the both sides of the specimen.

Midline.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the midline of the specimen.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

3D Conformal.value_description: A process by which a dose of radiation is automatically shaped to closely conform to the entire volume of the tumor, so that surrounding normal tissue is spared and treatment toxicity is decreased.

Intensity-Modulated Radiation Therapy.value_description: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy (3D CRT) that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3D CRT.

Proton Stereotactic Body Radiation Thera.value_description: Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) that utilizes a proton beam.

Photon Stereotactic Body Radiation Thera.value_description: Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) that utilizes a photon beam.

Proton.value_description: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.

Photon.value_description: A single unit of electromagnetic radiation, generally considered to be a discrete particle having no mass or charge.

Brachytherapy.value_description: A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Gy.value_description: A SI derived unit of absorbed radiation dose. One gray is equal to an absorbed dose of one joule per kilogram of matter, or to 100 rads.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Ovaries.value_description: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

PROTOCOL_PROCEDURE.variable_description: Was this procedure part of the treatment protocol?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

NON_PROTOCOL_TIMING.variable_description: If a non-protocol procedure, when was this procedure administered?

Prior to Study.value_description: The time period before the study.

After Study Completion.value_description: The time period after the completion of the study.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Primary.value_description: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Metastatic.value_description: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Soft Tissue.value_description: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Abdominal Wall.value_description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Adrenal.value_description: A bone located between the femur and the tarsus, being part of the lower leg.

Ankle.value_description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Ankle Joint.value_description: A gliding joint between the distal ends of the tibia and fibula and the proximal end of the talus.

Anus.value_description: The lower opening of the digestive tract, lying in the cleft between the buttocks, through which fecal matter is extruded.

Appendix.value_description: Small tissue projection existing as a cecal diverticulum with a questionable history of vestigial versus specialized organ.

Axilla.value_description: One of a pair of bones linking the scapula and the sternum. The clavicle is part of the pectoral girdle.

Axillary Nodes.value_description: One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.

Bladder.value_description: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Bone.value_description: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Bone Face.value_description: Any bone that contributes to the facial structures, except those bones that are part of the braincase.

Bone Foot.value_description: One of the seven tarsal, five metatarsal, or 14 phalangeal bones in the foot.

Bone Marrow.value_description: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Bone Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Brain.value_description: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Breast.value_description: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Bronchus.value_description: Tubular structure in continuation with the trachea, serving as air passage. It terminates in the lung (terminal bronchiole).

Carpal.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Celiac Nodes.value_description: A lymph node at the base of the celiac artery.

Cervical Nodes.value_description: Any of the lymph nodes located in the neck.

Cervical Spine.value_description: The set of vertebrae immediately caudal to the skull.

Chest Wall.value_description: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Colon.value_description: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

Cutaneous.value_description: Having to do with the skin.

Dorsal Spine.value_description: A spinal curve that originates at the middle of the second thoracic vertebra and terminates at the middle of the last thoracic vertebra.

Duodenum.value_description: A jointed tube 25-30 cm long that connects the stomach to the jejunum.

Elbow Joint.value_description: A type of hinge joint located between the forearm and upper arm.

Epididymis.value_description: A crescent-like structure located in the upper and posterior surfaces of the testis. It consists of the efferent ductules and the duct of the epididymis. It facilitates the maturation of sperm that is produced in the testis.

Epitrochlear or Brachial Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located above and adjacent to the elbow.

Esophagus.value_description: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Ethmoid Bone.value_description: A light and spongy bone that is cubical in shape. This bone is positioned at the anterior part of the cranium, sitting between the two orbits, at the roof of the nose. It consists of four parts: a horizontal or cribriform plate; a perpendicular plate; and two lateral masses or labyrinths.

Fallopian Tube.value_description: One of a pair of tubes that extend from the uterus to each of the ovaries. Following ovulation the egg travels down the fallopian tube to the uterus where fertilization may or may not occur.

Femur.value_description: The upper leg bone positioned between the pelvis and the knee.

Fibula.value_description: The small, lateral calf bone extending from the knee to the ankle.

Finger.value_description: Any of the digits of the hand.

Foot.value_description: The structure found below the ankle joint required for locomotion.

Forearm.value_description: The structure on the upper limb, between the elbow and the wrist.

Gallbladder.value_description: A pear-shaped organ located under the liver that stores and concentrates bile secreted by the liver. From the gallbladder the bile is delivered through the bile ducts into the intestine thereby aiding the digestion of fat-containing foods.

Gastrointestinal Tract.value_description: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Groin.value_description: The lower region of the anterior abdominal wall located laterally to the pubic region.

Hand.value_description: The distal portion of the upper extremity. It consists of the carpus, metacarpus, and digits.

Hand Phalanges.value_description: The hinge synovial joints between the phalanges of the fingers.

Head and Neck.value_description: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Heart.value_description: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

Hilar Nodes.value_description: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of perihilar bile duct cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system as they pertain to staging of regional lymph nodes.

Humerus.value_description: The upper arm bone between the shoulder and elbow.

Iliac Crest.value_description: The broad, dorsal, upper, and widest of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis.

Inferior Limb.value_description: A bone of the leg (lower extremity).

Infraclavicular Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the area below the clavicle.

Inguinal or Femoral Nodes.value_description: A superficial or deep lymph node located in the inguinal area.

Kidney.value_description: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secrete metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Knee.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Knee Joint.value_description: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Large Vessels.value_description: Any of the major arteries or veins attached to the cardiac atria or ventricles. This includes the aorta, superior and inferior vena cava and the pulmonary arteries and veins.

Larynx.value_description: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.

Leg.value_description: The portion of the lower extremity between the knee and the ankle. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole inferior limb.

Liver.value_description: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

Lower Limb.value_description: The limb that is composed of the hip, thigh, leg and foot.

Lumber Spine.value_description: Those vertebrae between the ribs and the pelvis, L1-L5 in man.

Lung.value_description: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Mandible.value_description: The lower jaw bone holding the lower teeth.

Maxilla.value_description: The upper jawbone in vertebrates; it is fused to the cranium.

Mediastinum.value_description: A Hodgkin lymphoma that arises from the mediastinum. It usually involves mediastinal lymph nodes and/or the thymus. Signs and symptoms include fever, weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats.

Meninges.value_description: Any one of three membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.

Mesenteric Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the mesentery.

Metacarpus.value_description: Any of the five bones between the wrist and the fingers that form the skeleton of the palm.

Metatarsus.value_description: A bone belonging to the middle part of the foot located between toes and ankle. There are 5 metatarsal bones and they are numbered from the medial side.

Nasal Septum.value_description: The thin wall between the two nasal cavities.

Neck.value_description: The region that connects the head to the rest of the body.

Oral Cavity.value_description: The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.

Orbit.value_description: The bony cavity of the skull which contains the eye, anterior portion of the optic nerve, ocular muscles and ocular adnexa. Seven bones contribute to the structure of the orbit: the frontal, maxillary, zygomatic, sphenoid, lacrimal, ethmoid, and palatine bones.

Ovary.value_description: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.

Pancreas.value_description: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

Para-aortic Lymph Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located adjacent to the lumbar region of the spine.

Paratesticular.value_description: A small anatomical compartment that contains the testicular collecting system, and mesothelial and mesenchymal components that represent extensions of the abdominal cavity and retroperitoneum.

Patella.value_description: A small flat triangular bone in front of the knee that articulates with the femur and protects the knee joint.

Pectoral Nodes.value_description: An axillary lymph node located along the lower edge of the pectoralis minor.

Pelvis.value_description: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Penis.value_description: The male organ of urination and copulation.

Peritoneum.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consists of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.

Pleural.value_description: The tissue that lines the wall of the thoracic cavity and the surface of the lungs.

Popliteal Nodes.value_description: Lymph node located within the fat layer of the knee joint.

Pre-auricular Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located anterior to the auricle of the ear.

Radius.value_description: The long bone of the forearm that extends from the lateral aspect of the elbow to the thumb-side of the wrist.

Rectum.value_description: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Retroperitoneum.value_description: The back of the abdomen where the kidneys lie and the great blood vessels run.

Rib.value_description: Any one of the paired bones, 12 on either side, extending from the thoracic vertebrae toward the median line on the ventral aspect of the trunk. The long curved bones which form the rib cage. Generally, ribs 1 to 7 are connected to the sternum by their costal cartilages and are called true ribs, whereas ribs 8 to 12 are termed false ribs.

Salivary Gland.value_description: An exocrine gland that secretes saliva. Salivary glands are mostly located in and around the oral cavity.

Sacrum.value_description: The triangular bone, made up of 5 fused bones of the spine, located in the lower area of the spine between the fifth lumbar vertebra and the coccyx.

Shoulder Girdle.value_description: The bony arch formed by the collarbones and shoulder blades.

Shoulder Joint.value_description: A ball-and-socket joint at the upper end of the humerus, located at the junction of humerus and scapula.

Skull and Face Bone.value_description: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Small Intestines.value_description: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Spine.value_description: A series of bones, muscles, tendons, and other tissues reaching from the base of the skull to the tailbone. The vertebral column forms the axis of the skeleton and encloses as well as protects the spinal cord and the fluid surrounding the spinal cord.

Spleen.value_description: An organ that is part of the hematopoietic and immune systems. It is composed of the white pulp and the red pulp and is surrounded by a capsule. It is located in the left hypochondriac region. Its functions include lymphocyte production, blood cell storage, and blood cell destruction.

Splenic Hilar Nodes.value_description: A lymph node located in the hilar region of the spleen.

Sternum.value_description: The long, flat bone connecting with the cartilages of the first seven ribs and the clavicle.

Stomach.value_description: An organ located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine. The stomach is the primary organ of food digestion.

Supraclavicular Nodes.value_description: A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

Tarsus.value_description: Any one of the seven bones forming the instep of the foot.

Testes.value_description: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

Thigh.value_description: A part of the lower limb, located between hip and knee.

Thyroid.value_description: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

Tibia.value_description: One of the terminal digits of the foot.

Tonsil.value_description: The two organs situated in the throat on either side of the narrow passage from the mouth to the pharynx. They are composed of lymphoid tissues.

Ulna.value_description: One of the bones that comprise the forearm. The largest aspect articulates with the humerus at the elbow joint and the smallest portion of the ulna articulates with the carpal bones in the wrist.

Upper Arm.value_description: The portion of the upper extremity between the shoulder and the elbow. For clinical purposes this term is also used to refer to the whole superior limb.

Upper Limb.value_description: The region of the body that includes the arm, the forearm, and hand.

Ureter.value_description: The thick-walled tube that carries urine from each kidney to the bladder.

Uterus.value_description: A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.

Vagina.value_description: The female genital canal, extending from the uterus to the vulva.

Vulva.value_description: The external, visible part of the female genitalia surrounding the urethral and vaginal opening. The vulva includes the clitoris and inner as well as outer labia.

Wrist Joint.value_description: A joint between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones.

Waldeyer's Ring.value_description: The ring of lymphoid tissue located in the pharynx, consisting of the pharyngeal, tubal, palatine, and lingual tonsils.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Left.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the left side of the specimen.

Right.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the right side of the specimen.

Bilateral.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the both sides of the specimen.

Midline.value_description: A finding indicating the tumor location is on the midline of the specimen.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Surgery.value_description: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Biopsy.value_description: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Fine Needle Aspiration.value_description: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Amputation.value_description: The surgical removal of all or part of a limb or other appendage.

Limb-salvage.value_description: A procedure to avoid amputation of an arm or leg.

Excision.value_description: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

Wide Resection.value_description: Surgery to cut out the cancer and some healthy tissue around it.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

AMPUTATION_TYPE.variable_description: The removal by surgery of a limb (arm or leg) or other body part because of injury or disease, such as diabetes or cancer. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Amputation - Through Involved Bone.value_description: The surgical removal of all or part of a limb or other appendage.

Amputation - Proximal to Involved Bone.value_description: A procedure to avoid amputation of an arm or leg.

Disarticulation.value_description: The surgical separation of bones at a joint.

Internal Hemipelvectomy.value_description: Unilateral removal of the pelvic girdle by resecting the innominate bone while preserving the ipsilateral limb.

External Hemipelvectomy.value_description: Unilateral removal of the pelvic girdle by resection of the innominate bone plus amputation of the ipsilateral limb.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

RESECTION_TYPE.variable_description: Surgery to remove tissue or part or all of an organ. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Intra-Articular Resection.value_description: A resection performed within a joint.

Extra-Articular Resection.value_description: A resection that is done outside the joint.

Intercalary Resection.value_description: A resection of a diaphyseal segment with the goal of preserving adjacent joints. This may include portions of the metaphysis and/or epiphysis depending on the extent of disease.

Internal Hemipelvectomy.value_description: Unilateral removal of the pelvic girdle by resecting the innominate bone while preserving the ipsilateral limb.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Endoprosthetic.value_description: An artificial device inserted to replace a missing part.

Osteoarticular Allograft.value_description: Grafting bone and cartilage that has been obtained from an individual of the same species as the intended recipient.

Intercalary Allograft.value_description: Grafting a segment of long bone that is obtained from an individual of the same species as the intended recipient.

Allograft-Prosthetic.value_description: Grafting a composite of an allograft and a prosthetic device.

Non-Vascularized Autograft.value_description: Harvesting a graft from the intended recipient that has no attached blood supply.

Vascularized Autograft.value_description: Harvesting a graft from the intended recipient that has attached blood supply.

Allograft + Vascularized Autograft.value_description: The combination of a bone graft from a donor of the same species and a graft from the intended recipient that has attached arteries and veins.

Vascularized Autograft Endoprosthetic Co.value_description: The combination of a graft from the intended recipient that has attached arteries and veins and a prosthetic device intended for implant.

Arthrodesis.value_description: Surgical fixation or immobilization of a joint, performed to allow bones to fuse or join together.

No Reconstruction.value_description: There was no surgical reconstruction performed.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Gross Total.value_description: Surgical removal of an entire visible lesion, with no obvious lesion detected on post-operative evaluation; microscopic residual disease may be present.

Complete Resection.value_description: Complete clearance of the tumor with histologically proved negative margins.

Partial Resection.value_description: Surgical removal of a part of a lesion; some portion of the lesion is detectable on post-operative evaluation.

Equivocal.value_description: A laboratory test result that indicates that a specific disease, condition, or attribute being assessed is not clearly present or absent.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

MARGINS.variable_description: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery. The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed. The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

R0 - Complete Resection, Negative Margin.value_description: No detectable presence of residual tumor after treatment

R1 - Complete Resection, Positive Margin.value_description: Presence of microscopic residual tumor after treatment.

R2 - Gross Residual Disease.value_description: Presence of macroscopic residual tumor after treatment.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

BIOPSY_TYPE.variable_description: The removal of cells or tissues for examination by a pathologist. The pathologist may study the tissue under a microscope or perform other tests on the cells or tissue. There are many different types of biopsy procedures. The most common types include: (1) incisional biopsy, in which only a sample of tissue is removed; (2) excisional biopsy, in which an entire lump or suspicious area is removed; and (3) needle biopsy, in which a sample of tissue or fluid is removed with a needle. When a wide needle is used, the procedure is called a core biopsy. When a thin needle is used, the procedure is called a fine-needle aspiration biopsy. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Core Needle Biopsy.value_description: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Incisional Biopsy.value_description: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Excisional Biopsy.value_description: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Thoracotomy.value_description: A surgical procedure in which an large incision is made into the chest wall, for the purpose of accessing organs inside the thoracic cavity.

Sternotomy.value_description: Incision into or through the sternum.

Video-Assisted Thoroscopic Surgery.value_description: Thoracic surgery that is aided by the use of a video camera.

Pneumonectomy.value_description: A lymph node located in the area below the clavicle.

Lobectomy.value_description: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

Wedge Resection.value_description: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

LOCALIZATION_TECHNIQUE.variable_description: The process of determining or marking the location or site of a lesion or disease. May also refer to the process of keeping a lesion or disease in a specific location or site. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

DISTANCE_MARGIN_TUMOR.variable_description: Closest Distance from Margin to Resected Tumor

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

SURGERY.variable_description: A procedure to remove or repair a part of the body or to find out whether disease is present. Also called operation. (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

NUMBER_NODES.variable_description: Involved Lymph Nodes Single or Multiple

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

AGE_AT_TMP_START.variable_description: Age in Days at Start of Transfusion Medicine Procedure

DISEASE_PHASE.variable_description: The phase of the cancer treatment process during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

DISEASE_PHASE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Disease Phase variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Relapse 1, Relapse 2, Relapse 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

COURSE.variable_description: The protocol treatment "course" during which relevant observations were recorded. This variable is used across domains to frame the timing of these longitudinal observations and reduce the number of redundant variables needed to report similar concepts (see "Disease Phase Timing and Course Table" in the documentation for additional guidance).

COURSE_NUMBER.variable_description: This variable indicates the ordinal numbering of the Course variable within its various subgroups (e.g., Induction 1, Induction 2, Induction 3, etc.). The observations across domains can therefore be organized longitudinally without the need for specific dates.

PROTOCOL_TRANSFUSION.variable_description: Was this transfusion part of the treatment protocol?

Yes.value_description: The affirmative response to a question.

No.value_description: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

NON_PROTOCOL_TIMING.variable_description: If a non-protocol transfusion, when was this transfusion administered?

Prior to Study.value_description: The time period before the study.

After Study Completion.value_description: The time period after the completion of the study.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Exchange Transfusion.value_description: Withdrawn blood is exchanged for other blood or blood components and returned to the subject.

Therapeutic Apheresis.value_description: Withdrawal of blood from a subject and removal of any pathogenic components before returning the remainder to the subject.

Simple Transfusion.value_description: Transfusion of blood into the body without removing any of the patient's blood volume.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

RBC.value_description: Red blood cells remaining after separating plasma from human blood, or collected by apheresis.

SCT_TYPE.variable_description: A procedure in which a patient receives healthy stem cells (blood-forming cells) to replace their own stem cells that have been destroyed by treatment with radiation or high doses of chemotherapy. The healthy stem cells may come from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or from a related or unrelated donor. A stem cell transplant may be autologous (using a patient’s own stem cells that were collected and saved before treatment), allogeneic (using stem cells from a related or unrelated donor), syngeneic (using stem cells donated by an identical twin), or cord blood (using umbilical cord blood donated after a baby is born). (Source: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms)

Autologous.value_description: Stem cell transfer or transplantation in which the patient is his own donor.

Allogeneic.value_description: A clinical treatment in which hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are transferred from one genetically dissimilar individual to another.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Bone Marrow.value_description: A procedure to replace diseased or pathologic bone marrow with transplanted healthy bone marrow cells.

Peripheral Blood.value_description: A method of hematopoietic reconstitution utilizing stem cells harvested from the circulating blood of a patient or donor. Peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) is used for the treatment of certain blood disorders, following partial or complete bone marrow ablation, or following high dose chemotherapy or radiation treatment for cancer. Immature circulating blood cells, similar to stem cells in the bone marrow, are removed before treatment. The cells are then given to the patient after treatment to help the bone marrow recover and continue producing healthy blood cells. Transplantation may be autologous (the patient's own blood cells are used), allogeneic (blood cells are donated by someone else), or syngeneic (blood cells are donated by an identical twin).

Cord Blood.value_description: A therapeutic procedure that involves the transplantation of hematopoietic stem cells collected from the umbilical cord or placenta.

Mixture of Stem Cells.value_description: A mixture of different sources of stem cells.

Other.value_description: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Biological Sibling.value_description: A person's brother or sister with whom they share a genetic makeup inherited from one or both of their shared biological parents.

Biological Parent.value_description: The male who supplied the sperm or the female who supplied the egg which resulted in one's conception.

Biological Relative.value_description: A person related by descent rather than by marriage or law.

Biologically Unrelated.value_description: A person who is biologically unrelated to another individual.

Unknown.value_description: Reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Match.value_description: The state when a recipient and their donor have the same alleles for tissue markers. A full match includes HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1. HLA match typing may also include alleles in the HLA-DQ serogroup.

Non-Match.value_description: The state when a recipient of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant is not fully matched with their donor for HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, and HLA-DRB1.

SCT_CONDITIONING_TYPE.variable_description: Type of Stem Cell Transplant Conditioning Prior to Transplant

Myeloablative.value_description: A conditioning regimen with high doses of chemotherapy or radiation to eliminate host hematopoietic stem cells prior to restitution via transplantation.

Reduced Intensity Conditioning/Reduced T.value_description: A method of preparation for stem cell transplant that uses less than standard doses of chemotherapy and radiation prior to the transfer of stem cells, with the goal of providing protection against graft vs. host disease, while simultaneously minimizing the toxic effects of the conditioning treatment.

Non-Myeloablative.value_description: A modification of the standard method of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation developed to allow for the therapy to be extended to a patient population that is unable to tolerate treatment with the conventional procedure due to its toxicity.
